The Turyn construction

Aug 21, 2019

Jeez, it’s been a long time since my last post. Sorry about that. The UChicago REU ended on Friday, and I got home yesterday. Other than the stuff I posted about, I spent a lot of time learning random parts of math, including the Atiyah-Singer index theorem and some 4-manifold theory. There are a ton of things I want to talk about: in this post, I’ll talk about the Turyn construction, but later, I want to talk about the Witten index and its relation to the Euler characteristic, signature, A-hat genus, and the Witten genus; immersions and embeddings of exotic spheres; exotic s; and James periodicity for the spectra, to name a few. (I’m writing these in part because I don’t want to forget to write posts on these topics.)

Onwards to the Turyn construction! I’d like to understand how one can go from the -lattice to the Leech lattice ; see Chapter 8.3 of Conway-Sloane. This is already intrinsically interesting, but another motivation comes from topology. In this post, we showed that there is a manifold whose Witten genus is . We know that the Witten genus of a Bott manifold is , so perhaps a manifold-level analogue of the Turyn construction will yield a string manifold whose Witten genus is . Working backwards, we might be able to find a manifold whose Witten genus is . Proving that this manifold is further divisible in the cobordism ring seems harder, but this’d at least be a start.

Let be a lattice with quadratic form (and associated bilinear form ), and let be a prime not dividing . Then there is an induced quadratic form . Suppose that , where and are isotropic subspaces which are self-dual with respect to . Let and denote the preimages of and in ; then and .

Fix some . If is a subspace of , define . Then if , we have that is an isotropic self-dual subspace. Moreover, the -dimensional lattice (with quadratic form ) is integral, and has determinant .

Now suppose and is the -lattice. We can choose , and then is an -dimensional -vector space. Then there is a unique (up to the action of the orthogonal group ) way of decomposing as . If , then the resulting -dimensional lattice can be showen to be an even unimodular lattice with minimal norm — by the uniqueness of the Leech lattice, that’s what it must be. More succintly, since and are copies of the -lattice, we have .

(A similar construction (again when and ) was used to produce an example of an extremal -dimensional lattice (so the first nonzero nonconstant term in its -function is the term, i.e., it has no nonzero vectors of norm or less).)

How do we emulate this sort of construction for manifolds? If is the oppositely oriented Kervaire-Milnor manifold obtained by plumbing along the -Dynkin diagram, then the String -manifold with Witten genus is . I can’t think of an analogue of the Turyn construction for manifolds.
